message: Cordelia isn't here.
It's not exactly the right time to come all the way here just to look something up. There's probably somewhere else she'd go.
This is in front of the once-glorious Miskatonic University.
Now it's an archives that tells the village's history, but villagers hardly ever visit, so this huge building stands there like a gravestone, utterly meaningless.
In front of the long-abandoned Miskatonic University, not a soul comes near even during the day, and at this hour, well past midnight, there’s definitely no one passing by.
Maybe because there's just no need for it, the main gate is still wide open just like during the day.
Even I wouldn't want to sneak into these creepy premises at this hour, but maybe they're trying to show that there's nothing worth stealing. Still, isn't this just way too careless?
Thick clouds still hang in the sky beyond the towering brick building, almost pressing down hard enough to crush the old structure.
In Arkham, where almost all the buildings are at most two stories tall, this Archives is the only high-rise. It looks just like the sole pillar holding up the sky.
How much longer can this brick building, given a lonely and noble life, fulfill its role?
As if to enhance the gloomy, damp atmosphere of Arkham, the thick clouds show no sign of clearing up.
This place must be, even on Great Britain, the most unsuitable land for people to live on.
How many times a year do the villagers living here get to see the sun? Or maybe this ominous weather is because of us, the out-of-place intruders who have wandered into Arkham.
Looking at the gloomy, overcast sky makes me feel kind of depressed too.
Maybe I shouldn't worry about it too much.
The exposed brick wall's dark brown has faded and started turning a pale pink. The large glass windows are rusting too, and it's anyone's guess how much longer they can hold up the weight.
It probably won't even take another 100 years before these school ruins collapse.
It does feel a bit of a shame, but there’s really no use for it just standing here like this.
The reason a university was built in such a remote village is probably thanks to the power of money Philip Dunwich brought in.
Dollie Dunwich ended up as the last president of the university that his own father built up by force.
Maybe that was a burden for Dollie too.
When my dad went missing and our savings ran dry, the village's finances started taking a nosedive.
The people who had any interest in Arkham gradually left the village...
Surely the villagers must have had it out for Dollie, the last head of the Dunwich family who supported the village.
The sharply sloping roof reminds me of the Church's bell tower.
Anyway, it just seems way too unnatural to be a university building...
What did Philip Dunwich, who built Miskatonic University here, seek in a university?
Did he just want to show off his wealth？
Or maybe, did they have some important purpose?
Because it's been neglected for a long time, the slate roof is cracked and being eroded by rainwater.
The elaborate design, which must have been crafted with the utmost care to intimidate anyone who looked at it, only stirs up pity now.
It was probably modeled after the University Museum in Oxford, my alma mater-the steep roofs and skylight windows remind me of that place.
Did Philip Dunwich, the founder of the university, want to make Arkham a city like Oxford, lined with Gothic-style spires?
If that's the case, then he's not a money-grubber like I thought he was.
Can't you just picture an upright man, like an old-time feudal lord, wishing for his land to flourish?
It probably used to boast an intimidating presence, but with slate peeling off here and there, you can't feel any of that old dignity at all.
Passing through the door that's left open, it looks like there's a grassy garden inside.
Judging from the building's exterior, it's not hard to imagine just how rundown the garden must be too.
With a university this big, it’s no surprise there are a bunch of dorms and even a chapel besides the main building.
But now, Arkham probably can’t afford to maintain those university buildings, which are nothing more than monuments.
The entrance door is left wide open, but maybe they assume no one would come near in the daytime, let alone sneak in at midnight.
Sure, it doesn’t seem like there’s anything here worth stealing, and if there was, it would’ve been taken a long time ago.
There’s no point in rummaging through these huge bookshelves all by myself...
Maybe I’ll just come back tomorrow or something.
